titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I left Birmingham at 8.45a.m. and arrived in York at 12.45p.m. After lunching in the hotel and getting my hair cut, I walked to S. William's college, and addressed a meeting of the Preventive and Rescue association. The other speaker was a rather nice–looking lady from Lawbridge, Mrs Rackham, who spoke well, but with a dangerously "feminist" bias. There were several reporters present, rather to my surprise, for I had supposed that this was a private meeting for workers, & my address was designed accordingly. After the meeting, I had tea at the Deanery, where the Archbishop picked me up, & carried me to Bishopthorpe, where we had a "small early dinner", & then returned for the "public meeting" at 8p.m. This was a failure. There was a small audience, & no reporters. This was the more annoying as my speech had been prepared with a direct view to making public my attitude of "Birth control" and "sex–education". However, it matters little, & it may well have been a good thing that my opinions on these grave questions should remain unknown. After the meeting we returned to Bishopthorpe, & talked on many things until after 11p.m. when we retired. The weather was foggy and then wet.
